title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced in CAR-NK cells in vivo
main_content: To further investigate the regulatory processes that govern the function of CAR19–IL-15 NK cells in vivo
context: We have previously shown that CAR19–IL-15 NK cells derived from cord blood exert potent activity in vivo (Ref: 14). We also analysed their single-cell transcriptional signatures after adoptive transfer in a non-curative mouse model of lymphoma developed using Raji cells (Ref: 14) (Fig. 1a).
outcome: we delved deeper into these single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) data

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced in CAR-NK cells in vivo
main_content: Uniform manifold approximation and projection (UMAP) clearly distinguished the transcriptional profiles of CAR19–IL-15 NK cells before and after infusion (Fig. 1b)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced in CAR-NK cells in vivo
main_content: Analyses of differentially expressed genes in CAR19–IL-15 NK cells after infusion revealed notable differences (Extended Data Fig. 1a), with the top upregulated genes including those that encode transcription factors such as CREM, FOS and ASCL2, among others

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced in CAR-NK cells in vivo
main_content: (missing)
context: given the well-established immunomodulatory role of the cAMP pathway and recent growing interest in targeting it to augment immunotherapy (Ref: 15-18)
outcome: We focused our attention on CREM

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced in CAR-NK cells in vivo
main_content: Elevated CREM expression in post-infusion samples (Fig. 1c and Extended Data Fig. 1b,c) correlated with optimal tumour control in vivo (Ref: 14)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced in CAR-NK cells in vivo
main_content: This response was characterized by an increased expression of effector genes such as GZMB (which encodes granzyme B), GZMH and GNLY, and genes related to calcium signalling, including S100A10, S100A6 and S100A4 (Fig. 1d and Extended Data Fig. 1d)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced in CAR-NK cells in vivo
main_content: these cells showed upregulation of genes associated with NK cell inhibition, including ADGRG1, KIR2DL3 and KLRG1 (Fig. 1e)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced in CAR-NK cells in vivo
main_content: CREM expression in CAR19–IL-15 NK cells remained consistent across all cell cycle stages (Extended Data Fig. 1e,f)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced in CAR-NK cells in vivo
main_content: analyses of IL-15 activity using CytoSig showed that it was significantly elevated after infusion (Extended Data Fig. 1g,h) and varied by cell cycle, with the highest levels observed in S phase (Extended Data Fig. 1i)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced in CAR-NK cells in vivo
main_content: We also observed a significant positive correlation between IL-15 activity and CREM expression after infusion, whereby both were increased (Extended Data Fig. 1j)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced in CAR-NK cells in vivo
main_content: Elevated CREM expression in post-infusion samples... correlated with optimal tumour control in vivo... increased expression of effector genes... upregulation of genes associated with NK cell inhibition... significant positive correlation between IL-15 activity and CREM expression
outcome: Collectively, these data suggest that CREM is induced in CAR-NK cells during peak antitumour activity and is associated with a transcriptional profile that balances both activation and regulatory functions

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CAR and IL-15 stimulation induce CREM
main_content: We next asked whether CREM is also induced in CAR-NK cells that target other antigens
outcome: To test this possibility, we engineered NK cells to express a CD70-targeting CAR using the CD27 receptor extracellular domain (ECD) (the natural receptor for CD70) fused to CD28 and CD3ζ signalling endodomains without an IL15 transgene (CAR70; Fig. 1f)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CAR and IL-15 stimulation induce CREM
main_content: (missing)
outcome: We also designed and tested CAR variants with altered signalling: one with mutated CD3ζ ITAM phosphorylation sites (CAR70.3ζ.Y6F) and another expressing only the CD27 ECD and therefore without intracellular signalling (CD27(ECD)); Fig. 1f and Extended Data Fig. 2a–c)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CAR and IL-15 stimulation induce CREM
main_content: Stimulation with CD70 antigen increased CREM expression only in CAR70 NK cells, but not in non-transduced (NT) NK cells or those expressing CARs that lack intracellular signalling (Fig. 1g)
outcome: This result confirmed the important role of ITAM signalling in CREM induction

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CAR and IL-15 stimulation induce CREM
main_content: We also investigated the effect of IL-15 on CREM induction in NK cells after cytokine starvation

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CAR and IL-15 stimulation induce CREM
main_content: IL-15 treatment resulted in a dose-dependent (50–5,000 pg ml⁻¹) increase in CREM expression (Fig. 1h) that was more substantial than with equivalent doses of IL-2 (Extended Data Fig. 2d) and was abrogated by IL-15 blockade (Extended Data Fig. 2e)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CAR and IL-15 stimulation induce CREM
main_content: stimulation of CAR70 NK cells with both CD70 antigen and exogenous IL-15 resulted in an additive increase in CREM expression (Extended Data Fig. 2f)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CAR and IL-15 stimulation induce CREM
main_content: Flow cytometry analyses revealed that both IL-15 receptor (IL-15R) expression and CREM levels increased with elevated IL-15 concentrations (Extended Data Fig. 2g), with significantly greater CREM expression in IL-15R⁺ than in IL-15R⁻ NK cells (Extended Data Fig. 2h)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CAR and IL-15 stimulation induce CREM
main_content: We next studied the kinetics of CREM induction after IL-15 stimulation and its relationship with Ki67

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CAR and IL-15 stimulation induce CREM
main_content: Although Ki67 increased at 48 h, CREM expression rose earlier and increased by 24 h (Extended Data Fig. 2i,j)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CAR and IL-15 stimulation induce CREM
main_content: CREM mRNA was upregulated as early as 6 h, peaked at 24–48 h and returned to baseline by 96 h (Extended Data Fig. 2k)
outcome: This finding indicated the occurrence of transient IL-15-induced expression

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CAR and IL-15 stimulation induce CREM
main_content: in our CAR–IL-15 system, in which IL-15 is constitutively secreted, CREM remained consistently high after transduction and after expansion with feeder cells and IL-2 treatment (Extended Data Fig. 2l)
outcome: which indicated that it was stably expressed

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CAR and IL-15 stimulation induce CREM
main_content: (missing)
context: CREM exists in more than 40 isoforms in humans... Some isoforms act as activators... whereas others function as repressors... By contrast, the inducible cAMP early repressor (ICER) isoforms... function exclusively as repressors (Ref: 23) (Extended Data Fig. 3a)
outcome: We quantified CREM-specific and ICER-specific transcripts in CAR-NK cells and after IL-15 stimulation (Methods)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CAR and IL-15 stimulation induce CREM
main_content: At baseline, NK cells expressed higher levels of CREM-specific transcripts than ICER-specific transcripts (Extended Data Fig. 3b). Compared with NT NK cells, CAR70–IL-15 NK cells showed upregulation of CREM-specific transcripts and, to a lesser extent, ICER-specific exon 2 transcripts (Extended Data Fig. 3b)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CAR and IL-15 stimulation induce CREM
main_content: IL-15 induced CREM-specific transcripts in a dose-dependent manner (Extended Data Fig. 3c)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CAR and IL-15 stimulation induce CREM
main_content: Using an antibody that recognizes all CREM gene products (Ref: 24,25), we confirmed expression of both CREM and ICER isoforms in NK cells, with CAR–IL-15 NK cells showing increased expression of multiple CREM isoforms above 20 kDa, including CREMα, CREMβ, CREMγ and CREMτ isoforms (Extended Data Fig. 3d,e)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CAR and IL-15 stimulation induce CREM
main_content: Stimulation with CD70 antigen increased CREM expression only in CAR70 NK cells... IL-15 treatment resulted in a dose-dependent... increase in CREM expression
outcome: Collectively, these findings indicate that both CAR ITAM signalling and IL-15 are potent inducers of CREM in NK cells, thereby highlighting their complex interplay in regulating NK cell activity

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: Cytokines and receptor signalling induce CREM
main_content: We examined the effects of various cytokines on CREM expression

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: Cytokines and receptor signalling induce CREM
main_content: IL-2, IL-12, IL-18 and IL-15 induced a dose-dependent increase in CREM, with IL-15 producing the strongest response. IL-10 and IL-21 had minimal effects on CREM levels (Extended Data Fig. 4a)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: Cytokines and receptor signalling induce CREM
main_content: To assess the role of ITAM signalling through endogenous NK cell receptors
outcome: we stimulated NK cells with anti-CD16, anti-NKp30 and anti-NKp46 antibodies (Extended Data Fig. 4b)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: Cytokines and receptor signalling induce CREM
main_content: which similarly upregulated CREM expression (Extended Data Fig. 4c)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: Cytokines and receptor signalling induce CREM
main_content: IL-2, IL-12, IL-18 and IL-15 induced a dose-dependent increase in CREM... endogenous NK cell receptors... similarly upregulated CREM expression
outcome: These results suggest that CREM upregulation is a general feature of NK cell activation that is driven by both cytokine and ITAM-based signalling and with stimulus-specific differences in strengths and kinetics

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is upregulated in tumour-infiltrating NK cells
main_content: We next explored CREM expression in the context of NK cell exhaustion in the tumour microenvironment
outcome: Analyses of scRNA-seq datasets from the TISCH2 database

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is upregulated in tumour-infiltrating NK cells
main_content: Analyses of scRNA-seq datasets from the TISCH2 database revealed broad CREM expression in tumour-infiltrating immune cells, especially NK cells, T cells and monocytes and macrophages, but minimal expression in malignant or stromal cells

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is upregulated in tumour-infiltrating NK cells
main_content: Tumour-infiltrating NK (TI-NK) cells showed higher CREM expression than NK cells in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs), especially those from bladder cancer, cholangiocarcinoma and lung cancer (Extended Data Fig. 5a)
context: This pattern held across multiple cancer types in the TI-NK cell atlas, in which CREM was consistently increased in TI-NK cells compared with PBMC NK cells (Ref: 26) (Extended Data Fig. 5b)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is upregulated in tumour-infiltrating NK cells
main_content: To further validate these findings
outcome: we analysed TI-NK cells from nine patients with pancreatic cancer treated at the MD Anderson Cancer Center, including five primary tumours and four metastatic lesions (Ref: 27)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is upregulated in tumour-infiltrating NK cells
main_content: CREM expression was highest in metastatic TI-NK cells compared with PBMCs or primary tumours (Extended Data Fig. 5c), and ranked among the top 50 differentially active regulons in the transcriptome of metastatic TI-NK cells (Extended Data Fig. 5d,e)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is upregulated in tumour-infiltrating NK cells
main_content: Analyses of data from The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) showed that high CREM expression generally correlated with poor survival in several cancers, including low-grade glioma, lung adenocarcinoma, stomach adenocarcinoma and breast invasive carcinoma (Extended Data Fig. 5f)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is upregulated in tumour-infiltrating NK cells
main_content: CREM was enriched in mature NK1 clusters from an atlas of NK cell heterogeneity (Ref: 28) (Extended Data Fig. 5g)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is upregulated in tumour-infiltrating NK cells
main_content: CREM was consistently increased in TI-NK cells compared with PBMC NK cells... CREM expression was highest in metastatic TI-NK cells... CREM was enriched in mature NK1 clusters
outcome: Collectively, our findings indicate that CREM is prominently expressed in TI-NK cells across various cancers and that, in a healthy context, its expression is associated with a more mature NK cell phenotype

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM shapes the NK cell phenotype
main_content: to determine the phenotype of CREM-expressing NK cells

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM shapes the NK cell phenotype
main_content: CAR70–IL-15 NK cells consistently expressed the highest levels of CREM, followed by CAR70 and IL-15 NK cells (Extended Data Fig. 6a–c)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM shapes the NK cell phenotype
main_content: Six distinct clusters emerged (clusters 1–6), with clusters 1 (highest CREM expression), 2 and 4 predominantly found in CAR70–IL-15, CAR70 and IL-15 NK cells, respectively (Fig. 1j,k and Extended Data Fig. 6d–g)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM shapes the NK cell phenotype
main_content: Cluster 1 was characterized by higher levels of activation markers (NKG2D, CD25, CD2, GZMB and perforin) and inhibitory markers (NKG2A, LAG3, TIGIT and TIM3; Fig. 1l)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM shapes the NK cell phenotype
main_content: CREM was associated with higher expression of both activation and inhibitory markers across all conditions (Extended Data Fig. 6i)
outcome: a result that supports the link between CREM induction and a phenotype of activation-induced exhaustion

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM shapes the NK cell phenotype
main_content: CAR70–IL-15 NK cells consistently expressed the highest levels of CREM... Cluster 1 was characterized by higher levels of activation markers... and inhibitory markers... CREM was associated with higher expression of both activation and inhibitory markers
outcome: Collectively, our data support the notion that CREM is preferentially induced by strong NK cell activation, such as through CAR signalling and IL-15 stimulation, and its expression is associated with a complex immunophenotype characterized by both activation and exhaustion

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced through the PKA–CREB axis
main_content: to determine whether the canonical PKA–CREB axis is involved in CREM induction after NK cell activation
context: CREM is regulated through the cAMP signalling pathway (Ref: 29), in which increases in intracellular cAMP levels activate protein kinase A (PKA), which in turn phosphorylates transcription factors such as CREB and CREM. These factors then bind cAMP-response elements to regulate the transcription of target genes (Ref: 30)
outcome: we measured phosphorylated CREB (pCREB) levels in NK cells after CAR or IL-15 stimulation

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced through the PKA–CREB axis
main_content: CAR stimulation resulted in marked CREB phosphorylation in CAR70 NK cells but not in NT or CAR-NK cells with mutated or absent CD3ζ signalling (CAR70.3ζ.Y6F and CD27(ECD), respectively; Fig. 2a,b)
context: These data paralleled previous observations of CREB phosphorylation by PKA downstream of T cell receptor (TCR) signalling (Ref: 31)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced through the PKA–CREB axis
main_content: Pretreatment of NK cells with H89, a PKA inhibitor, strongly inhibited CAR-induced CREB phosphorylation and CREM induction after CAR ligation (Fig. 2b–d)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced through the PKA–CREB axis
main_content: (missing)
context: Given the established function of calcium as an activator of PKA (Ref: 32,33) and its pivotal role in the immune cell activation cascade (Ref: 34)
outcome: we also chelated calcium with EGTA

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced through the PKA–CREB axis
main_content: Treatment with EGTA led to a consistent suppression of CAR-induced CREB phosphorylation and CREM induction (Fig. 2b–d)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced through the PKA–CREB axis
main_content: Similarly, we observed activation of this pathway in NK cells stimulated through ITAM-associated CD3ζ downstream of CD16, NKp30 and NKp46, which was effectively inhibited by PKA or calcium blockade (Extended Data Fig. 7a,b)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced through the PKA–CREB axis
main_content: IL-15 resulted in a dose-dependent increase in PKA activity (Extended Data Fig. 7c) and pCREB levels in NK cells (Fig. 2e–i), whereas CREB phosphorylation and the subsequent increase in CREM expression were effectively blocked by H89 (Fig. 2j and Extended Data Fig. 7d,e) and EGTA (Extended Data Fig. 7f,g)
outcome: Together, these data provide support for a pivotal role of the PKA–CREB axis in CREM upregulation in response to CD3ζ or IL-15 stimulation

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced through the PKA–CREB axis
main_content: Chromatin immunoprecipitation and quantitative PCR (ChIP–qPCR) assays confirmed strong enrichment of CREB on the CREM promoter (promoter 1; Extended Data Fig. 3a) in CAR70–IL-15 NK cells (Fig. 2k)
context: The parallel patterns of CREB phosphorylation and CREM induction after CAR ligation or IL-15 stimulation suggested that CREM might be a direct target of CREB

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced through the PKA–CREB axis
main_content: treatment of NK cells with increasing doses of IL-15 led to a dose-dependent increase in binding of pCREB to the CREM promoter (Fig. 2l)
context: These patterns of CREB and pCREB enrichment correlated with CREM transcription levels in these cells under the same conditions (Fig. 1h and Extended Data Fig. 6a)
outcome: which strongly indicated that CREM is directly regulated by CREB

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced through the PKA–CREB axis
main_content: To determine the role of STAT3 and STAT5 in IL-15-mediated CREM induction
context: IL-15 activates NK cells through the JAK–STAT pathway, specifically STAT3 and STAT5... IL-15 induced a dose-dependent increase in pSTAT3 and pSTAT5... By contrast, CAR activation alone did not induce pSTAT3 or pSTAT5
outcome: we assessed CREM expression after IL-15 stimulation in wild-type (WT), STAT3 knockout (KO; Extended Data Fig. 7l), STAT5A and STAT5B (STAT5A/B) KO (Extended Data Fig. 7m) and CREM KO NK cells

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced through the PKA–CREB axis
main_content: CREM levels were partially reduced in both STAT3 KO and STAT5A/B KO NK cells (Extended Data Fig. 7n)
outcome: which indicated that both these factors are involved in CREM induction

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced through the PKA–CREB axis
main_content: ChIP analysis did not reveal significant pSTAT3 binding at the CREM promoter (promoter 1; Extended Data Fig. 3a), whereas STAT5B binding was significantly enriched after IL-15 treatment (Extended Data Fig. 7o,p)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced through the PKA–CREB axis
main_content: CREM levels were partially reduced in both STAT3 KO and STAT5A/B KO NK cells... ChIP analysis did not reveal significant pSTAT3 binding... whereas STAT5B binding was significantly enriched
outcome: Our findings indicate that both STAT3 and STAT5 regulate CREM expression, either indirectly (STAT3) or directly through promoter binding (STAT5)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM is induced through the PKA–CREB axis
main_content: CREM induction also occurred independently of STAT signalling, specifically after CAR stimulation in the absence of pSTAT3 and pSTAT5, and instead depended on the PKA–pCREB axis (Fig. 2b–d and Extended Data Fig. 7j,k)
outcome: These findings collectively highlight a dual mechanism of CREM regulation in CAR-NK cells through the PKA–CREB signalling axis and through STAT3–STAT5 downstream of IL-15

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO enhances CAR-NK cell potency
main_content: To determine whether CREM functions as a negative regulator in CAR-NK cells
context: Our analyses indicated a complex interplay among CAR activation, cytokine signalling and CREM induction
outcome: we used CRISPR–Cas9 to KO CREM (an exon shared by most of the non-ICER isoforms) in two CAR-NK cell models: (1) CAR70–IL-15 NK cells... and (2) TROP2-targeting CAR-NK cells

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO enhances CAR-NK cell potency
main_content: CREM KO significantly enhanced the cytotoxicity of CAR–IL-15 NK cells in long-term two-dimensional and three-dimensional tumour spheroid cultures and in tumour rechallenge assays, particularly at low effector-to-target ratios (Fig. 3a–d, Extended Data Fig. 8a–d and Supplementary Videos 1–4)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO enhances CAR-NK cell potency
main_content: Furthermore, CREM KO enhanced the cytotoxicity of IL-15, CAR70 and CAR70–IL-15 NK cells in tumour rechallenge assays (Fig. 3e and Extended Data Fig. 8e) and their ability to produce cytokines (Fig. 3f), with no effect on NT NK cells
outcome: Together, these data suggest that NK cell activation through CAR and/or IL-15 stimulation drives CREM expression to act as an intracellular checkpoint

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO enhances CAR-NK cell potency
main_content: To further elucidate the contributions of CAR signalling and IL-15 on CREM induction
outcome: we tested the activity of NK cells expressing different constructs... on UMRC3 spheroids

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO enhances CAR-NK cell potency
main_content: CREM KO enhanced CAR-NK cell cytotoxicity in conditions in which CAR activation or IL-15 signalling was present, with the greatest effect observed when both pathways were active (CAR70–IL-15; Fig. 3g,h)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO enhances CAR-NK cell potency
main_content: (missing)
outcome: We tested CAR-NK cell cytotoxicity against CD70 KO UMRC3 cells (Extended Data Fig. 8f)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO enhances CAR-NK cell potency
main_content: CREM KO enhanced the effector function of IL-15-secreting NK cells, regardless of tumour expression of the cognate antigen, but had no effect on CAR70 NK cells without IL-15 (Extended Data Fig. 8g)
outcome: This result suggests that CREM acts as an inhibitory checkpoint downstream of IL-15 stimulation or CAR signalling after antigen engagement

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO enhances CAR-NK cell potency
main_content: CREM KO did not have a significant effect on the function of NT NK cells; however, after exposure to increasing concentrations of exogenous IL-15, CREM KO led to enhanced cytotoxicity against tumour targets (Extended Data Fig. 8h)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO enhances CAR-NK cell potency
main_content: CREM KO significantly enhanced the cytotoxicity of CAR–IL-15 NK cells... CREM KO enhanced the cytotoxicity of IL-15, CAR70 and CAR70–IL-15 NK cells... CREM KO enhanced the effector function of IL-15-secreting NK cells... CREM KO did not have a significant effect on the function of NT NK cells
outcome: Together, these data point to an important role for CREM as a potent intracellular immune checkpoint that restrains NK cell antitumour activity in response to either CAR or IL-15 stimulation

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO improves CAR-NK cell in vivo activity
main_content: We evaluated the impact of CREM KO on CAR-NK cell function in vivo
outcome: using three different NOD/SCID IL-2Rγnull (NSG) mouse models of haematological and solid tumours

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO improves CAR-NK cell in vivo activity
main_content: To model NK cell exhaustion
outcome: we used a mouse model of aggressive CD70⁺ Raji Burkitt lymphoma and treated these mice with long-term cultured (23-day-old) NT, CREM WT or KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells at a subtherapeutic dose (Fig. 4a)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO improves CAR-NK cell in vivo activity
main_content: Treatment with CREM KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells led to significantly enhanced tumour control compared with CREM WT CAR70–IL-15 NK cells, NT NK cells or untreated controls (Fig. 4b,c), and resulted in improved survival (Fig. 4d)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO improves CAR-NK cell in vivo activity
main_content: Moreover, CREM KO led to increased proliferation of CAR70–IL-15 NK cells in peripheral blood (Fig. 4e) and greater infiltration into the lungs, liver, bone marrow and spleen (Fig. 4f)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO improves CAR-NK cell in vivo activity
main_content: Notably, the administration of CREM KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells did not cause toxicity, as evidenced by stable body weights in treated mice (Extended Data Fig. 9a)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO improves CAR-NK cell in vivo activity
main_content: We also studied the dynamics of ex vivo function and cytokine production of CREM WT and KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO improves CAR-NK cell in vivo activity
main_content: By day 10 after infusion, CREM WT CAR70–IL-15 NK cells acquired a dysfunctional phenotype, with reduced cytotoxicity against targets in Raji and K562 cells compared with the original infusion product (Extended Data Fig. 9b–e). By contrast, CREM KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells maintained their cytotoxic function at this early time point (Extended Data Fig. 9b–e)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO improves CAR-NK cell in vivo activity
main_content: Serum analyses for human cytokines revealed increased levels of TNF, IFNγ, granzyme family members, perforin and other effector molecules in mice treated with CREM KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells, particularly at later time points, which indicated different dynamics of cytotoxicity and cytokine production (Extended Data Fig. 9f)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO improves CAR-NK cell in vivo activity
main_content: (missing)
outcome: In a metastatic CD70⁺ breast cancer PDX model, NSG mice were engrafted with BCX.010 cells and received intravenous treatment of NT, CREM WT CAR70–IL-15 or CREM KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells 7 days later or were left untreated (Fig. 4g)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO improves CAR-NK cell in vivo activity
main_content: Mice treated with CREM KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells showed significantly lower tumour burden than all control groups (Fig. 4h and Extended Data Fig. 9g)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO improves CAR-NK cell in vivo activity
main_content: CREM KO also led to increased proliferation of CAR-NK cells in peripheral blood and greater infiltration into the lungs and liver (Fig. 4i–l), accompanied by elevated GZMB expression (Fig. 4k,l)
outcome: a result consistent with an activated NK cell phenotype

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO improves CAR-NK cell in vivo activity
main_content: In an independent experiment using the same model, CREM KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells led to increased survival of mice compared with controls (Fig. 4m)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO improves CAR-NK cell in vivo activity
main_content: (missing)
outcome: These results were further validated in an orthotopic TROP2⁺ PATC148 mouse model of pancreatic cancer (Extended Data Fig. 9j)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO improves CAR-NK cell in vivo activity
main_content: Intraperitoneal injection of CREM KO CAR.TROP2–IL-15 NK cells led to improved tumour control (Extended Data Fig. 9k) and in vivo systemic persistence (Extended Data Fig. 9l)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO improves CAR-NK cell in vivo activity
main_content: We further investigated the safety of CREM KO CAR-NK cells using our BCX.010 mouse model
context: Targeting inhibitory checkpoints in NK cell activation raises the possibility of unwanted toxicity
outcome: mice with BCX.010 tumours were treated intravenously with either CREM WT or KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells... As a control, we infused CREM KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells into mice without tumours

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO improves CAR-NK cell in vivo activity
main_content: histological analyses of major organs (liver, lungs and kidneys) did not show notable abnormalities attributable to NK cell therapy in mice treated with either CREM WT or KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells (Extended Data Fig. 10a)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO improves CAR-NK cell in vivo activity
main_content: In a separate cohort, blood collected from mice with BCX.010 tumours 30 days after infusion of NK cells did not show significant differences in haematological parameters or serum chemistry between mice treated with CREM WT or KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells (Extended Data Fig. 10b–d)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM KO improves CAR-NK cell in vivo activity
main_content: Treatment with CREM KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells led to significantly enhanced tumour control... did not cause toxicity... increased survival of mice compared with controls
outcome: In summary, our findings support the therapeutic potential of CREM KO to enhance the efficacy of CAR-NK cells in vivo while maintaining a favourable safety profile, thereby highlighting the translational relevance of this approach

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: To understand how CREM modulates CAR-NK cell function
outcome: we performed ChIP–seq using an antibody that recognizes all CREM isoforms to identify genome-wide CREM-binding sites in NK cells

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: CREM binding was detected across numerous genomic sites, and antibody specificity was confirmed by the enrichment of CREM motifs under ChIP–seq peaks (Fig. 5a)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: CREM occupancy was higher in IL-15, CAR70–IL-15 and CAR70 NK cells than in NT NK cells (Fig. 5b and Extended Data Fig. 11a), a pattern that was also observed for core CREM-binding target genes (Fig. 5c)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: CREM-bound genes included those relevant to NK cell activity (chemokines and cytokines), cytotoxicity molecules (IFNG, LAMP1 and GZMB), calcium signalling (CAMK1D, CAMK2D and CAMLG) and genes with regulatory function (FOS, FOSB, NFKB2, NFKBIA, STAT3 and EGR1)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: Hallmark pathway enrichment analysis of CREM target genes identified the MYC targets V1 as the top pathway enriched among all conditions (Fig. 5d and Extended Data Fig. 11b)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: (missing)
context: Given the dual function of CREM as both a transcriptional repressor and activator with tissue-specific and cell-specific expression (Ref: 35)
outcome: we performed integrative analysis of our ChIP–seq and RNA-seq data from CREM WT and KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: CREM KO led to both the upregulation and downregulation of direct CREM target genes (Extended Data Fig. 11c)
outcome: a result that underscores its context-specific regulatory functions

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: consistently downregulated target genes in CREM KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells included those related to exhaustion and stress responses... Conversely, CREM KO upregulated genes involved in NK cell cytotoxicity such as GZMB and IFNG, and transcription factors implicated in T cell and NK cell development (KLF7 and RUNX2)
context: included those related to exhaustion and stress responses, including BTG1 (Ref: 36), DUSP2 (Ref: 37), SMAD3, NFKB2 (Ref: 3) and RGS1 (Ref: 8)... implicated in T cell and NK cell development (Ref: 38,39)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: Gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA) of direct CREM targets revealed that CREM KO upregulated pathways crucial for NK cell effector function and metabolism, including MYC and E2F targets, MTORC1 signalling and oxidative phosphorylation. In parallel, it downregulated immunosuppressive pathways such as hypoxia and TGFβ signalling (Fig. 5e and Extended Data Fig. 11e,f)
outcome: Together, these data suggest that CREM contributes to NK cell dysfunction by directly binding and upregulating exhaustion and stress-related genes while suppressing pathways essential for NK cell function and proliferation

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: To assess the overall impact of CREM on the epigenome
outcome: we analysed differences in chromatin accessibility between CREM WT and CREM KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells cultured alone or with UMRC3 cells using assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with sequencing (ATAC–seq)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: Overall, CREM WT CAR70–IL-15 NK cells displayed reduced chromatin accessibility when cultured together with tumour cells, whereas CREM KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells maintained a more open chromatin landscape under the same conditions (Fig. 5f)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: Notably, CREM KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells cultured together with tumour cells retained accessibility in most cellular metabolic and effector pathways, including MTORC1, PI3K–AKT–MTOR signalling and the mitotic spindle (Extended Data Fig. 11g)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: Compared with CREM WT, CREM KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells showed enrichment of chromatin accessibility at loci associated with activation of E2F targets, oxidative phosphorylation, MYC targets, G2M targets, MTORC1 signalling and the mitotic spindle (Extended Data Fig. 11h)
outcome: a result consistent with an effector, activated and proliferating NK cell phenotype

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: Indeed, genes associated with effector function (for example, GZMA and PRF1) and transcription factors essential for NK cell maturation and function (for example, EOMES and TBX21) showed increased accessibility in CREM KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells (Fig. 5g and Extended Data Fig. 11i)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: Motif enrichment analysis revealed that binding motifs for JUN-related factors (JUND, JUNB, FOSL1–JUND and FOSL1), STAT factors and CEBP factors were highly enriched in CREM KO compared with WT CAR70–IL-15 NK cells, whereas ETS-related factors were among the most differentially enriched in CREM WT compared with KO cells (Fig. 5h,i and Extended Data Fig. 11j)
context: These patterns of enriched AP-1 and closed ETS motifs mirror epigenetic signatures associated with long-lived memory T cells (Ref: 40)
outcome: and may underlie the enhanced persistence and function of CREM KO CAR-NK cells

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: To further dissect the mechanisms by which CREM KO improves NK cell function
outcome: we first assessed IL-15R proximal signalling

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: Expression of IL-15R signalling components was comparable between CREM WT and CREM KO NK cells, with some donor-to-donor variability (Extended Data Fig. 12a,b)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: Similarly, levels of negative regulators of IL-15R signalling, including SOCS1 and CISH, were not significantly different (Extended Data Fig. 12a,c)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: We next investigated whether CREM KO mirrors the biological effects of IL-15R signalling in NK cells, including enhanced proliferation, extended lifespan and improved metabolic fitness

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: CREM KO CAR-NK cells showed increased proliferation and extended lifespan, particularly in vivo (Fig. 4e,f,i,j and Extended Data Fig. 9i,l)
context: In keeping with our transcriptomic data of upregulated cell cycle pathways

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: Moreover, metabolic functional assays revealed enhanced glycolytic capacity and a trend towards increased mitochondrial respiration in CREM KO CAR70–IL-15 NK cells (Extended Data Fig. 12d–i)

title: CREM is a regulatory checkpoint of CAR and IL-15 signalling in NK cells
subsection: CREM alters the CAR-NK cell genetic landscape
main_content: CREM regulates NK cell function by modulating gene expression and chromatin states and by promoting a dysfunctional state
outcome: Taken together, these findings indicate that CREM regulates NK cell function by modulating gene expression and chromatin states and by promoting a dysfunctional state (Fig. 5j)
